results.title: People on Sunday
results.creator_credit: Edgar G. Ulmer, Robert Siodmak and Filmstudio
results.brief_description: This pioneering low-budget film made at the very end of the silent era, was an avant-garde blend of feature and documentary. Its lyrical recording of the streetlife of everyday Berlin owes something to the cycle of ‘city symphony’ films popular in the mid-Twenties. Onto this documentary background is grafted a simple narrative focusing on the interactions between five young Berliners—all played by non-professional actors—who spend a typical Sunday together in and around Berlin. The film launched the careers of all six principal filmmakers involved, and had a huge influence on subsequent film movements including the French New Wave, Italian Neorealist and British Free Cinema movements. This restored version contains important scenes previously missing and features a new score by Elena Kats-Chernin. Written by Billie Wilder, Curt Sidomak and Robert Sidomak. Photography, Eugen Schufftan and Fred Zinnemann. Based on an original story by Curt Siodmak.

results.title: Peel
results.brief_description: A red-headed family’s drive in the countryside begins an intrigue of awesome belligerence and obstinacy. This short student drama from the director of ‘The Piano’ (2003) was the winner of the Palme d’Or for best short film at Cannes in 1986. Original format 16 mm/colour.

results.title: Pee Wee's big adventure
results.creator_credit: Tim Burton, Richard Gilbert Abramson, Robert Shapiro, Aspen Film Society and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Pee Wee Herman’s Big Adventure is Tim Burton’s feature film direction debut. It is the surreal tale of Pee Wee Herman, the grown-up kid with impeccable dress sense, and his most prized possession, his awesome bicycle. When Pee Wee discovers it has been stolen from outside Chuck’s Bike-o-rama, he is devastated and embarks on the long journey to find it. He hits the open road and encounters riotous adventures with bikers, bums, cowboys, an escaped con man, a phantom trucker and a waitress who dreams of travelling to Paris. His quest leads him to the Warner Brothers studio in Hollywood where security is tight and Pee Wee’s bike is in the hands of a spoilt child star. He eventually manages to steal it back drawing the interest of a Hollywood producer who makes Pee Wee’s story into a James Bond send-up. The latter includes special appearances by James Brolin, who stars as P.W. Herman and Morgan Fairchild, his assistant and lover. Includes music by Danny Elfman. Cast includes: Pee Wee Herman, Elizabeth Daily, Mark Holton, Diane Salinger and Judd Omen.

results.title: Pecker
results.creator_credit: John Waters, Mark Tarlov, John Fiedler, Polar Entertainment and Fine Line Features
results.brief_description: Written and directed by John Waters (Pink Flamingos, Hairspray, Serial Mom), ‘Pecker’ is an offbeat comedy set in Baltimore, Waters’ hometown. Pecker (Edward Furlong) is a happy-go-lucky 18 year old who likes nothing better than to take candid photographs of his eccentric family and friends, as well as unusual aspects of his environment. Pecker’s family consist of: Mom (Mary Kay Place) who spends her days dispensing fashion tips to the homeless; sister Tina (Martha Plimpton) who spruiks at a local gay strip bar; grandmother, (Jean Schertler) who receives religious messages from her Holy statue of Mary; and six year old sister Chrissy who is suffering from an eating disorder. Shelly (Christina Ricci) is Pecker’s girlfriend who runs a laundromat and encourages his artistic endeavours. At an exhibition of his work, Pecker is “discovered” by Rorey (Lili Taylor), a New York art dealer who promises him fame and fortune. Pecker’s notoriety brings public ridicule to those nearest and dearest to him and threatens the integrity of his art. Also starring Mink Stole, Bess Armstrong, Brendan Sexton III, with a cameo from photographer Cindy Sherman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Waters, Mark Tarlov, John Fiedler, Polar Entertainment and Fine Line Features

results.title: Patty Hearst
results.creator_credit: Paul Schrader, Marvin Worth and Zenith Productions
results.brief_description: In 1974 Californian newspaper heiress Patty Hearst (Natasha Richardson), was kidnapped and allegedly brainwashed by terrorists from the Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA). She caused public scandal when she rejected the offer for freedom after 57 days of being confined in a closet and becoming a successful bank robbing urban guerilla. Also starring William Forsythe, Ving Rhames and Frances Fisher. Based on the book “Every secret thing” by Patricia Campbell Hearst and Alvin Moscow.

results.title: Passport to Pimlico
results.creator_credit: Henry Cornelius, Sir Michael Balcon and Ealing Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forever Ealing”.
This was the first classic Ealing comedy. An ancient document reveals that London’s Pimlico district really belongs to France. The community eager to abandon post-War constraints, particularly rationing establish their independence as a ration-free state with hilarious results. Stars Stanley Holloway, Hermione Baddeley and the wonderful Margaret Rutherford.

results.title: Paris, Texas
results.creator_credit: Wim Wenders, Anatole Dauman, Don Guest, Road Movies and Argos Films
results.brief_description: Travis (Harry Dean Stanton) is travelling aimlessly through Texas, having left behind his son in LA with his successful brother Walt (Dean Stockwell). But Travis decides to go back for his son and take him along on a journey to find the boy’s mother (Nastassja Kinski). Their search ends in a cheap strip- joint and Travis and his ex-wife confront each other about lost dreams and past betrayals. Visually striking, and intellectually stimulating, “Paris, Texas” is scripted by Sam Shepard and based on his own volume of short stories, “Motel chronicles”. The haunting musical score is by Ry Cooder.

results.title: Paragraph 175
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Friedman, Robert Epstein, Home Box Office, Channel Four Films and Telling Pictures
results.brief_description: This documentary about the Nazi persecution of homosexuals during the Third Reich, reveals the lasting consequences of this little known chapter of 20th century history through the personal recollections of six survivors. Between 1933 and 1945, 100,000 men were arrested for homosexuality under Paragraph 175, the unenforced sodomy provision of the German penal code dating back to 1871. Some were imprisoned, others were sent to concentration camps. Of the latter, only about 4,000 survived. By the 1920s, Berlin had become known as a homosexual Eden where gay men and lesbians lived relatively open lives amidst a thriving community of artists and intellectuals, however with the coming to power of the Nazis, Paragraph 175 was revived to brutally crush this culture. Combined with archival images and an historical account of gay culture preceding and during the Third Reich, the moving testimonies of the now very elderly five men and one women raise provocative questions about memory, history, and identity. In English, German and French with English subtitles.

results.title: Outland
results.creator_credit: Peter Hyams, Richard Roth and The Ladd Company
results.brief_description: On Io, the innermost moon of Jupiter, the volcanic landscape is desolate. For the Con-Am 27 mining colony, populated by misfits and losers, it is home. Violence bubbles benath the surface, ready to explode. Federal District Marshall, William T. O’Niel, (Sean Connery), is sent to investigate the grisly, frenzied deaths amongst the miners, and must struggle alone in the pursuit of truth. This is a grim view of the future, where productivity takes precendence over humanity.

results.title: Oscar and Lucinda
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Timothy White, Robin Dalton and Fox Searchlight
results.brief_description: Based on Peter Carey’s Booker Prize-winning novel, Gillian Armstrong’s “Oscar and Lucinda” is a lyrical story about chance, fate and love. Set in the 19th century it tells the story of how two eccentric characters are brought together by fate and an obsession with gambling. Lucinda Leplastrier (Cate Blanchett) is an unconventional woman living in a society obsessed with normality. She uses her inheritance to buy a glassworks factory in Sydney. Returning from London by ship she meets Oscar Hopkins, a strange Anglican minister terrified by the ocean but compulsively attracted to gambling. When their paths meet again in Sydney they embark on an incredible mission to take a glass church into the heart of the Australian bush. With a cast of wonderful Australian and British actors, Cate Blanchett shines in a role which heralded her international film career. Laura Jones has done a good job of translating Carey’s dense novel to the screen, and Luciana Arrighi’s production design and Geoffrey Simpson’s cinematography create a sumptuous backdrop to the characters’ journeying.
